text: Who wrote the letter of 2 Timothy?
verseText: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God according to the promise of the life that is in Christ Jesus,

text: What is the likely situation of Paul as he writes 2 Timothy?
options: Imprisoned again in Rome, shortly before his death
verseText: Therefore do not be ashamed of the testimony about our Lord, nor of me his prisoner... May the Lord grant mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, for he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chains... For I am already being poured out as a drink offering, and the time of my departure has come. I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.

text: 2 Timothy has the tone of a final charge or testament from Paul to whom?
verseText: To Timothy, my beloved child... I charge you in the presence of God and of Christ Jesus... preach the word; be ready in season and out of season...

text: Paul encourages Timothy not to be ashamed but to 'fan into flame' what (2 Timothy 1)?
options: The gift of God within him
verseText: For this reason I remind you to fan into flame the gift of God, which is in you through the laying on of my hands, for God gave us a spirit not of fear but of power and love and self-control.

text: What does Paul exhort Timothy to do with the gospel message he has received (2 Timothy 2)?
options: Entrust it to faithful men who will be able to teach others also
verseText: and what you have heard from me in the presence of many witnesses entrust to faithful men, who will be able to teach others also.

text: Paul uses metaphors like a soldier, an athlete, and a farmer in 2 Timothy 2 to illustrate what qualities needed for ministry?
options: Endurance, discipline, and hard work focused on the goal
verseText: Share in suffering as a good soldier of Christ Jesus. No soldier gets entangled in civilian pursuits, since his aim is to please the one who enlisted him. An athlete is not crowned unless he competes according to the rules. It is the hardworking farmer who ought to have the first share of the crops.

text: What does Paul famously state about 'All Scripture' in 2 Timothy 3:16?
options: It is God-breathed (inspired) and profitable for teaching, reproof, correction, and training in righteousness
verseText: All Scripture is breathed out by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof, for correction, and for training in righteousness,

text: In 2 Timothy 4, Paul gives Timothy a solemn charge to do what?
options: Preach the word; be ready in season and out of season
verseText: preach the word; be ready in season and out of season; reprove, rebuke, and exhort, with complete patience and teaching.

text: As Paul faces his imminent death, what does he declare he has done (2 Timothy 4)?
options: Fought the good fight, finished the race, kept the faith
verseText: I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.

text: Who does Paul say deserted him, 'in love with this present world' (2 Timothy 4)?
verseText: For Demas, in love with this present world, has deserted me and gone to Thessalonica...

text: What specific gift does Paul remind Timothy to 'fan into flame'?
options: The gift of God given through the laying on of hands
verseText: For this reason I remind you to fan into flame the gift of God, which is in you through the laying on of my hands,

text: According to Paul, what kind of spirit did God NOT give us?
verseText: for God gave us a spirit not of fear but of power and love and self-control.

text: Paul asks Timothy to join him in what, according to the power of God?
verseText: Therefore do not be ashamed of the testimony about our Lord, nor of me his prisoner, but share in suffering for the gospel by the power of God,

text: Who does Paul mention as having refreshed him often and not being ashamed of his chains?
verseText: May the Lord grant mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, for he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chains,

text: What should a 'good soldier of Christ Jesus' avoid getting entangled in?
verseText: No soldier gets entangled in civilian pursuits, since his aim is to please the one who enlisted him.

text: What must an athlete do to receive the victor's crown, according to Paul's analogy?
verseText: An athlete is not crowned unless he competes according to the rules.

text: Paul tells Timothy to remind others to avoid quarreling about what, as it does no good?
verseText: Remind them of these things, and charge them before God not to quarrel about words, which does no good, but only ruins the hearers.

text: How should Timothy present himself to God?
options: As a worker approved, rightly handling the word of truth
verseText: Do your best to present yourself to God as one approved, a worker who has no need to be ashamed, rightly handling the word of truth.

text: What does Paul say will spread like gangrene?
verseText: But avoid irreverent babble, for it will lead people into more and more ungodliness, and their talk will spread like gangrene.

text: What inscription is on the 'firm foundation of God'?
options: 'The Lord knows those who are his,' and, 'Let everyone who names the name of the Lord depart from iniquity.'
verseText: But God's firm foundation stands, bearing this seal: 'The Lord knows those who are his,' and, 'Let everyone who names the name of the Lord depart from iniquity.'

text: In a large house, besides gold and silver vessels, what other kinds are there?
verseText: Now in a great house there are not only vessels of gold and silver but also of wood and clay, some for honorable use, some for dishonorable.

text: What should Timothy flee from?
verseText: So flee youthful passions and pursue righteousness, faith, love, and peace, along with those who call on the Lord from a pure heart.

text: How should the Lord's servant correct opponents?
verseText: And the Lord's servant must not be quarrelsome but kind to everyone, able to teach, patiently enduring evil, correcting his opponents with gentleness.

text: Paul warns that in the last days, people will be lovers of what?
verseText: But understand this, that in the last days there will come times of difficulty. For people will be lovers of self, lovers of money...

text: Paul lists characteristics of people in the last days. Which of these is NOT mentioned?
options: Lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God
verseText: For people will be lovers of self, lovers of money, proud, arrogant, abusive, disobedient to their parents, ungrateful, unholy, heartless, unappeasable, slanderous, without self-control, brutal, not loving good, treacherous, reckless, swollen with conceit, lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God, having the appearance of godliness, but denying its power.

text: Who does Paul compare the false teachers of Timothy's day to, who opposed Moses?
verseText: Just as Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses, so these men also oppose the truth, men corrupted in mind and disqualified regarding the faith.

text: Paul reminds Timothy of the persecutions he endured in which locations?
verseText: my persecutions and sufferings that happened to me at Antioch, at Iconium, and at Lystraâ€”which persecutions I endured; yet from them all the Lord rescued me.

text: What does Paul say will happen to all who desire to live a godly life in Christ Jesus?
options: They will have an easy life
verseText: Indeed, all who desire to live a godly life in Christ Jesus will be persecuted,

text: From whom did Timothy learn the sacred writings (Scriptures)?
options: His mother Eunice and grandmother Lois (from childhood)
verseText: I am reminded of your sincere faith, a faith that dwelt first in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice and now, I am sure, dwells in you as well... But as for you, continue in what you have learned and have firmly believed, knowing from whom you learned it and how from childhood you have been acquainted with the sacred writings...

text: Besides teaching, reproof, and correction, what else is Scripture profitable for?
verseText: All Scripture is breathed out by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof, for correction, and for training in righteousness,

text: What is the ultimate purpose of Scripture, according to Paul's statement?
options: To make one wise for salvation through faith
That the man of God may be complete, equipped for every good work
verseText: ...and how from childhood you have been acquainted with the sacred writings, which are able to make you wise for salvation through faith in Christ Jesus... that the man of God may be complete, equipped for every good work.

text: Paul charges Timothy in the presence of God and Christ Jesus, who will judge whom?
verseText: I charge you in the presence of God and of Christ Jesus, who is to judge the living and the dead, and by his appearing and his kingdom:

text: Paul warns that a time is coming when people will not endure what?
verseText: For the time is coming when people will not endure sound teaching, but having itching ears they will accumulate for themselves teachers to suit their own passions,

text: Instead of listening to the truth, what will people turn aside to?
verseText: and will turn away from listening to the truth and wander off into myths.

text: What qualities should Timothy exhibit in all circumstances?
options: Be aggressive, seek fame, build wealth
Be always sober-minded, endure suffering, do the work of an evangelist, fulfill your ministry
Be cautious, avoid conflict, stay hidden
Be popular, please everyone, compromise doctrine
verseText: As for you, always be sober-minded, endure suffering, do the work of an evangelist, fulfill your ministry.

text: What imagery does Paul use to describe his approaching death?
options: Being poured out as a drink offering
verseText: For I am already being poured out as a drink offering, and the time of my departure has come.

text: What does Paul say is laid up for him, which the Lord will award him?
verseText: Henceforth there is laid up for me the crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous judge, will award to me on that day...

text: Who else besides Paul will receive the crown of righteousness?
options: All who have loved his appearing
verseText: ...and not only to me but also to all who have loved his appearing.

text: Paul asks Timothy to come to him quickly. Who is the only one currently with Paul?
verseText: Luke alone is with me...

text: Who does Paul ask Timothy to pick up and bring with him, because he is helpful in ministry?
verseText: Get Mark and bring him with you, for he is very useful to me for ministry.

text: What items did Paul leave with Carpus at Troas that he wants Timothy to bring?
options: The cloak and the books, especially the parchments
verseText: When you come, bring the cloak that I left with Carpus at Troas, also the books, and above all the parchments.

text: Who does Paul warn Timothy about, stating 'he strongly opposed our message'?
verseText: Alexander the coppersmith did me great harm; the Lord will repay him according to his deeds. Beware of him yourself, for he strongly opposed our message.

text: What happened at Paul's first defense?
options: No one stood by him; all deserted him
verseText: At my first defense no one came to stand by me, but all deserted me. May it not be charged against them!

text: Despite being deserted, who stood by Paul and strengthened him during his defense?
verseText: But the Lord stood by me and strengthened me, so that through me the message might be fully proclaimed and all the Gentiles might hear it.

text: Paul expresses confidence that the Lord will rescue him from what?
verseText: The Lord will rescue me from every evil deed and bring me safely into his heavenly kingdom.

text: Who does Paul send greetings to at the end of the letter?
options: Prisca and Aquila, and the household of Onesiphorus
verseText: Greet Prisca and Aquila, and the household of Onesiphorus.

text: Where did Paul leave Erastus, and where did he leave Trophimus sick?
options: Erastus in Ephesus, Trophimus in Crete
Erastus in Corinth, Trophimus in Miletus
Erastus in Rome, Trophimus in Jerusalem
Erastus in Antioch, Trophimus in Cyprus
verseText: Erastus remained at Corinth, and I left Trophimus, who was ill, at Miletus.

text: Paul urges Timothy to try and come before what season?
verseText: Do your best to come before winter.

text: Besides Timothy, who else sends greetings in the closing remarks?
options: Eubulus, Pudens, Linus, Claudia, and all the brothers
verseText: Eubulus sends greetings to you, as do Pudens and Linus and Claudia and all the brothers.

text: What is Paul's final blessing for Timothy?
options: May you have a long life
May you become a great leader
The Lord be with your spirit. Grace be with you.
verseText: The Lord be with your spirit. Grace be with you.
